newsitem.title: UK: Sheep-cloners test cystic fibrosis drug in people.
newsitem.headline: Sheep-cloners test cystic fibrosis drug in people.

text.p: British scientists who created the first cloned adult mammal -- Dolly the sheep -- said on Wednesday they would start clinical trials of a protein to treat cystic fibrosis.
PPL Therapeutics will test the protein, produced by the genetically engineered sheep in their milk, at Papworth Hospital in Cambridge.
Dr Ron James, managing director of PPL, said Britain's Medicines Control Agency had allowed the tests on 12 volunteers with cystic fibrosis.

The protein, alpha-antitrypsin (AAT), is a human protein. The sheep bred at PPL's joint laboratory with the Roslin Institute near Edinburgh have been bred to express human genes that "code" for production of the protein.
Cystic fibrosis is deadly and there is no cure. Victims suffer lung and intestinal damage.
AAT is a treatment for the symptoms of cystic fibrosis, not a cure. It helps correct the lung tissue breakdown.
